newsitem.title: USA: DRI/McGraw Hill says China bank problem "enormous".
newsitem.headline: DRI/McGraw Hill says China bank problem "enormous".

text.p: U.S. economic forecasting firm DRI/McGraw Hill said Tuesday that China's troubled banking sector represents one of the most serious threats to global market stability.

China's banking problem is "enormous," DRI/McGraw Hill said in a survey of the world's biggest emerging markets. Within the next three to five years, China could default on between 20 and 40 percent of the country's $600 billion in outstanding loans, it added.

"... The risk of (China's) serious debt problem will continue to mount and could have major economic ramifications for many of China's smaller and weaker economic neighbours," the report, entitled "Country Risk Review", said.

Chinese banks have been crippled by government policies that force them to make questionable loans to state-owned or state-sponsored companies, many of which are in very weak financial positions, the report said.
DRI/McGraw Hill made its comments on China as it ranked the relative investment risk of the world's big emerging markets.
Among the 10 countries surveyed, South Africa presented the highest investment risk due to a declining rate of growth and rising unemployment and inflation.
South Africa's mineral and agricultural output is stagnant or falling and consumer debt has reached dangerous proportions, the report said.

While South Africa recently had its sovereign debt rating upgraded and has increased its foreign reserves, "the general dismal fundamentals of the South African government and economy are expected to lead to poor long-term prospects" for the country, it added.
After South Africa and China, the report listed Indonesia, Russia and Brazil, in descending order, as having the highest investment risk.
Argentina, Poland, Mexico, Turkey and India offered the lowest investment risk among the biggest emerging markets, the report said.
